title: FOIA Request for Surveillance Camera Data (Dougherty County Sheriff)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents relating to procurement, deployment (including location), maintenance, and any other use related issues (including "hot list" details) of video or image surveillance cameras deployed throughout the city including, but not limited to those cameras made by Flock Safety. Further, any documents detailing results, complaints, and frequency of access of the cloud-based storage, including protocols for the request of the same.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

David J. Gregors, Esquire

title: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Public Records Request for Data on School Policing
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law


I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

katherine stathulis

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. To whoever it may concern: 

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, G.L. c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your school district. A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement

e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.

Northeastern University School of Law

Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act,  school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE).   DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement.  DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.  

A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”  

A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”   


I request the following public records, as defined in G. L. c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth): 

1.	An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a.	Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b.	Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c.	Charge (or charges)
d.	Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e.	Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f.	Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g.	Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h.	Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i.	Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j.	Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k.	Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and 
l.	Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2.	If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide school incident reports on each school-related arrest and referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022 school year (up until the day the records are produced). 

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

3.	A copy of any active standard operating procedures developed with the police department and/or other law enforcement agencies regarding police placement or activity in your corresponding school;  and,

4.	Any records instructing or informing police personnel of, or otherwise describing data reporting requirements and procedures for complying with G.L. c. 71 § 37P(b).

5.	The cost to the school district of assigning a school resource officer to each school; and, 

6.	The total number of school resource officers and total number of guidance counselors for each school in your district for school years 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and,

7.	The total number and a brief description of 911 calls from schools in your district to local police departments conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, and 2021-2022, and, 

8.	A description of the proposed budget for mental, social, or emotional health support personnel for the school district.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act.  “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”    

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your school district may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty.  Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
 
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. G.L.c. 66, § 6A(d). 

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply.  To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.

If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me by phone at (617)-373-5862 or by email at k.stathulis@northeastern.edu. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.
	
Sincerely, 


Katherine Stathulis, Esq.
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
Northeastern University School of Law

title: Response to HB7, "Stop WOKE Act"

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

1) Any record reflecting any request for "guidance from the FLDOE" referenced in President Williams' January 11, 2023 memo to Chancellor Hebda, and any record reflecting any "guidance" received.

2) Any agenda for, minutes of, audio or video recordings (including Zoom recordings) of, or notes taken at any of the following meetings:
(a) a meeting on December 14, 2022  of the Council of Presidents
(b) a meeting on January 4, 2023 with Chancellor Hebda on the one hand and any member of the Council of Presidents (including President Williams) on the other;
(c) a meeting on January 5, 2023 between President Williams and Florida College System presidents, as referenced in President Williams' January 6, 2023 email with the subject line "Executive Order Framework";
(d) a meeting on January 17, 2023 at or about 6:30 p.m. with Chancellor Hebda on the one hand and any member of the Council of Presidents (including President Williams) on the other;
(e) the COP Professional Development meeting held on or about January 18, 2023;
(f) a coordination call held on February 2, 2023 by the Moore Agency. This meeting may have been attended by persons employed within the college's media/public relations staff.

3) Any copy of remarks presented (or talking points, notes, or similar preparatory materials) by President Williams at the February 1, 2023 faculty assembly.

4) Any emails (including attachments) sent to or from Williams.Tonjua@spcollege.edu which contain any of the "SEARCH TERMS" identified below. This request is limited to records generated on or after January 1, 2022.

5) Any emails (including attachments) sent (on or after November 1, 2022) to, from, or between Williams.Tonjua@spcollege.edu, on the one hand, and any of the following addresses, on the other hand: agarciafalconetti@polk.edu, parkera@palmbeachstate.edu, probstc@scf.edu, cflax-hyman@gulfcoast.edu, dstephenson@nwfsc.edu, emeadows@pensacolastate.edu, lorenzg@seminolestate.edu, ghaile@broward.edu, BigardH@LSSC.EDU, henningj@cf.edu, richeyj@easternflorida.edu, jdudley1@fsw.edu, MURDAUGJ@tcc.fl.edu, joepickens@sjrstate.edu, John.Avendano@fscj.edu, grosskopfj@nfcc.edu, Jonathan.gueverra@cfk.edu, Katwater@hccfl.edu, kplinske@valenciacollege.edu, lawrence.barrett@fgc.edu, mpumarie@mdc.edu, Paul.broadie@sfcollege.edu, CLEMMONSS@chipola.edu, thomas.leitzel@southflorida.edu, timmoore@irsc.edu, beardt@phsc.edu, tlobasst@daytonastate.edu, Kathy.Hebda@fldoe.org, or Henry.Mack@fldoe.org

6) Any draft of the FCS Presidents Statement (also known as the "COP Statement on HB 7") issued on or about January 18, 2023.  This includes copies of any draft circulated by email and any Word version (including any redline version) sent to or from President Williams. This includes drafts circulated under any title, including (but not limited to) "FCS Presidents Statement", "Florida College System Presidents Statement on Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Critical Race Theory", and "COP Statement on HB 7".

7) Any records reflecting or relating to the review on or about January 2, 2023 by Chancellor Hebda of the FCS Presidents Statement.

8) Any emails to or from President Williams concerning the "Executive Order Framework" as referenced in her January 6, 2023 email.

9) Any records reflecting the submission of a statement on HB 7 on or about December 14, 2022, as referenced in President Williams' December 14, 2022 email with the subject line "COP Statement on HB 7".

10) Any records reflecting any response to the December 14, 2022 submission from any state official or appointee.

11) Any text messages sent to or from President Williams and any member of the Council of Presidents on or after November 1, 2022.

12) Any emails (including attachments), text messages, or other communications between President Williams on the one hand and either Chancellor Henry Mack or Chancellor Kathryn Hebda on the other hand on or after November 1, 2022.

13) Emails (including attachments) sent to or from Matthew Liao-Troth or Jamelle Connor on or after December 1, 2022 containing any of the "SEARCH TERMS" identified below.

14) Any emails sent to or from President Williams or any person employed within the college's media/public relations staff, on the one hand, and the Moore Agency (including Kendra or Karen Moore: kendrap@themooreagency.com, KarenM@themooreagency.com), on or after January 1, 2023.

title: Public Records Request - Drug charge referrals (San Francisco Public Defender)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

On 2/17/23, this statement appeared in the San Francisco Standard that is attributed to Bill Ong Hing, an immigration law professor at the University of San Francisco:

"Hing said the city should instead focus on providing counseling and outreach to noncitizen dealers to guide them away from selling fentanyl. He runs a program that does exactly that with referrals from the Public Defender’s Office and the District Attorney’s Office in San Francisco.

“We have a very good success rate,” Hing said. “We’re proud of that fact, that’s how you get them off the street.”

Please provide all referrals, data and scope of program related to this program for the years 2020 to present.  In the instance of needing to protect identity, redaction of names is permissible. 

Also, provide the same parameter to other programs that provide "counseling and outreach to noncitizen dealers to guide them away from selling..." drugs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Gina McDonald

title: Missing Person Case File: David Robert Sampson

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Missing Person Case File: David Robert Sampson
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all case files, information, data, photos, investigative notes, logs, presentations, communications, written notes, documentation, documents, official emails, any and all public outreach media or print media and any communications either to or from NCIC or WACIC (either email or teletype) about a missing man named DAVID ROBERT SAMPSON. SAMPSON went missing from the city of Seattle on March 1st of 1977. 

The agency case file for this missing person request is: 84-195323. There is a NAMUS case number of: 14272. The case appears to be currently assigned to Thomas Jensen, who is retired and a volunteer with the King County Sheriff's Office cold case squad. Efforts to reach Mr. Jensen have been unsuccessful.. Two PDFs are attached related to this missing person case. 

I am filing this request because I believe that there is a possibility that SAMPSON could be the identity of an unidentified John Doe discovered in Kirkland in 1985. I hope that this request spurs a comparison between SAMPSON and the Kirkland John Doe, and that this request ensures that public information related to SAMPSON is available. 

Thank you to the King County Sheriff's Office for their commitment to transparency, and I look forward to working together on this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robert Delaware

title: Death Records  - Imperial County Sheriff’s Office

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Death Records  - Imperial County Sheriff’s Office
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Unidentified Remains Policy Guidance 
Any policy, procedure, manual, guidance document, or post order maintained by the Imperial County Sheriff’s Office regarding identification, documentation, return, or disposal of human remains located within the County limits as described in the Imperial SD Policy Manual (v. 2023/2/01) at page 257 under section 334.2.4 - UNIDENTIFIED DEAD BODIES (available at https://icso.imperialcounty.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/RELEASE_20230201_T161156_Imperial_County_SD_Policy_Manual.pdf). We are seeking any further clarification on ISCO’s process for creating “John Doe” or “Jane Doe” numbers for the Coroner’s case report, as required by Section 334.2.4. Please provide any records of guidance in effect between January 1, 2005 and January 1, 2021. 

2. ICSO John Doe Death Report Records 
Any ICSO document listing by date and/or case number all reports for unidentified dead bodies (“John Doe” or “Jane Doe” reports) created by ICSO in concert with the Coroner’s Office pursuant ICSO Policy 334.2.4 between January 1, 2005 - January 1, 2021. If these records could be produced in the form of a single spreadsheet, we would accept that in lieu of any more labor-intensive search. 

3. Public Administrator’s Office Remains Disposal Records 
All records of disposal of remains of decedents by the ICSO Public Administrator’s Office as referenced at page 258 of the ICSO Policy Manual under section 334.2.8(c) (‘If the decedent appears to be indigenes and the Public Administrators Office is assuming the responsibility for the burial of the decedent, all of the decedent’s property being retained by the Coroner’s Office shall be released to the Public Administrators Office.”). Please include all records of property transfers as well as records of burials for indigent John or Jane Doe remains. This request seeks records from January 1, 2005, through January 1, 2021. 

4. Death Notification Records Pursuant to 334.2.3
Records of notifications by ICSO or the Coroner’s Office or a designee, pursuant to ICSO Policy 334.2.3 to any foreign consulate regarding a death handled by the ICSO or Coroner of any person: (a) believed to be a migrant and non-resident of Imperial County, California or another U.S. County; or (b) whose identified cannot be verified but who was identified as missing by a consular official. Please provide records for January 1, 2019 - January 1, 2021. 

5. Coroner Request Records Pursuant to 334.2.1
Any ICSO record showing the total number of Coroner Requests made by year which fall within subsections (a) (“unattended deaths”); (f) (“criminal or suspected criminal action”); (i) (“accident or injury”); (j); and/or (p) of Section 334.2.1 of ICSO’s Policy Manual for the years 2005-2021. 

Requester info: 
I make this request on behalf of Marni LaFleur, Associate Professor of Anthropology at University of San Diego. These records will be used for academic, non-commercial purposes. Bio here: https://www.sandiego.edu/directory/biography.php?profile_id=7039

Fee waiver request: 
Because these records are being sought for educational and academic purposes, we respectfully request a fee waiver. In the event fees are required, we agree to pay up to $25 without notification. If the total search and reproduction fees exceed $25, please notify us at MarniLaFleur@sandiego.edu and Andrew@detentionkills.org. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within the statutorily required period. 

If you have any questions regarding request, require additional information to fulfill, or would like to proposal an alternative production protocol, please contact us at MarniLaFleur@sandiego.edu and Andrew@detentionkills.org. 


Sincerely,

Andrew Free

  * Tracking Number: FCC-2023-000373 
  * Requester Name:
					Landon Edwards 
  * Date Submitted: 02/21/2023 
  * Request Status: Submitted 
  * Description:
					To Whom It May Concern: 

In its frequency waiver requests for certain Satellite Earth Station (SES) license application filings*, applicant Harte Satellite Consultants states that "Grant of this waiver is in the public interest. This earth station will be part of a test and training network allowing U.S. government customers to acquaint themselves with the service in the United States prior to using the service elsewhere in the world. Grant of this waiver request is in the public interest as it allows for utilization of available satellite capacity to provide U.S. government customers with service for critical testing and training exercises." 

*said SES license applications having the file numbers SES-LIC-20220125-00083, SES-LIC-20220125-00084, SES-LIC-20220125-00085, SES-LIC-20220125-00086, SES-LIC-20220125-00087, SES-LIC-20220125-00088, SES-LIC-20220125-00089, and SES-LIC-20220125-00090. 

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records: 

Any supporting documents, records, or communications between the applicant and the FCC pertaining to the above statement made by applicant or otherwise supporting applicant's claim(s) of public interest. 

If the FCC is in possession of additional records which are relevant to or otherwise pertain to a supposed business relationship between Harte Satellite Consultants and "U.S. government customers", please consider those responsive to this request. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Landon Edwards 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Ffederal-communications-commission-46%252Ffcc-ibfs-ses-hsc-141058%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AAAkDjvjktNmt-jZL_eGYomHkf4%3A1pUgf2%3A93UucX7NKQ_l9tVa1nDY1jOQsbIp34XlRa8VEkfEfjY
